data.title: Prevent the resize handle from covering the center
data.body:
Currently, the absolutely positioned element is the only thing with a
size. That means that it'll cover the center. With this change, we give
a size to the (relatively-positioned) atom-dock element so that closed
docks take up canvas space instead.

I think @simurai mentioned this problem before but I wasn't following
and then forgot about it. ðŸ˜–

cc @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Remove event listeners from correct element
data.body: Just noticed that these event listeners were being removed from the wrong elements.

data.title: Opening/reloading Atom focuses Tree View
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Opening or reloading Atom focuses the Tree View instead of whatever was focused last, eg the file you were working on.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have the Tree View and a file open
2. Focus the file
3. Reload Atom

OR

1. Open an existing project that has files open with Atom

**Expected behavior:** After the open/reload finishes, to be able to continue typing like nothing happened

**Actual behavior:** Tree View has focus, so typing will trigger Tree View shortcuts

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0-dev-a13887d25
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
```
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

Windows 10 x64.  Not sure if this is a core bug or related to Tree View, so filing it here first.

data.title: Always focus active pane item when pane is activated
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14173

This regressed in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14143

data.title: Avoid errors deserializing 1.17 workspace state in prior Atom versions
data.body:
We're seeing errors that break window startup when deserializing 1.17 workspace state in prior Atom versions. Since users switch back and forth between beta and stable, this could cause unnecessary confusion. Here we don't provide full compatibility when downgrading, but we at least avoid errors so the window starts up gracefully. Unfortunately, we'll need to cherry-pick this to 1.17-releases.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Switching tabs does not focus editor
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After switching tabs, the focus does not get transferred to the editor.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open two tabs and activate the first tab.
2. Click on the second tab to switch to it.

**Expected behavior:** Be able to start typing immediately

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens when you type.  Instead, you have to click on the editor first.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.17.0-dev-4b77f9050
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

This may only be on the Electron 1.6.x branch.  In addition, it also happens when reloading the window, in which case the Tree View gets focus.

data.title: Atom freezes when opening large binary files
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I have large binary files in the tree (JARs >1GB). I know I shouldn't open them in Atom, but sometimes I misclick and open one of these. In that case Atom freezes with `Loading Archive` message. If the file is not too big, it will eventually load, but editor is not usable during this time. If the file is too big it will eventually display a message where I can either _wait more_ or _close_. Unfortunately the _close_  closes the entire window.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a directory containing a large (binary) file
2. (Mis)click the file in Atom
3. Atom freezes while the file is loaded 

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

One or more of the following:

* Atom asks if I want to open this file (normally you don't open large binary files, for large text files you might want to say yes and wait a bit)
* Atom starts loading, but UI remains responsive so I can close the tab and continue working
* Atom displays a preview but requires additional action to actually open the file
* When Atom eventually asks if I want to kill the process, just close the tab, don't kill the whole window

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

* Atom UI freezes, making it unusable for > 1 min
* Atom asks if I want to close the file, but this closes entire window

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Always for a sufficiently large file

### Versions

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Mac OS X 10.12.4 (16E195)

data.title: Atom drain CPU and Memory when opening a project with babel-cli installed locally
data.body:
### Prerequisites
This issue has been reproduce under "safe mode", "a new atom profile" and "a new atom profile under safe mode".

### Description
atom cause high cpu usage and memory drain when opening a project babel-cli installed under node_modules folder

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a folder and open terminal
2. execute `npm install babel-cli`
3. Open atom
4. Click "File" menu and click "Add Project Folder", then select the folder we just created, then we'll see the folder tree view will be shown in the sidebar
3. Close atom
4. Open atom again
5. Atom with high cpu usage and continuously memory drain (in extreme condition, i open atom for hours, it cosumes all my available memory and atom crashes)

additional: remove the folder from project immediately solve the problem(both cpu usage and memory drain)

### Versions
current lasted version
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
System: Windows 10 enterprise x64 14393

### Additional Information
node version v7.7.1
npm version
{ npm: '4.1.2',
  ares: '1.10.1-DEV',
  cldr: '30.0.3',
  http_parser: '2.7.0',
  icu: '58.2',
  modules: '51',
  node: '7.7.1',
  openssl: '1.0.2k',
  tz: '2016j',
  unicode: '9.0',
  uv: '1.11.0',
  v8: '5.5.372.41',
  zlib: '1.2.11' }

screenshots:
![cpu and memory usage](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2271900/24898745/792c9682-1ed0-11e7-9904-aee07bdf9338.png)
pic above:around 6-7 minutes of opening atom and leaving it doing nothing(cpu e3 1230v2), eats me 3G memory and constant cpu usage


## problem solved
I'm using `cnpm`(https://npm.taobao.org/), a customized version of npm install modules, which might cause circle symbol links that cause this issue, after using `npm` this issue no longer exists.

data.title: Fix adding bundled packages to `ModuleCache` and increase test coverage
data.body:
This morning I noticed that bundled packages were not being added to the `ModuleCache`. This was due to an accidentally committed change in 681f0f9fe1ca40425342102f01b0f1f406013858 and, since we had very little test coverage, this problem unfortunately slipped through.

This pull request adds back `ModuleCache.add` and retrofits some tests for that code path and for the new packages preloading stuff too.

data.title: Compared with Notepad++ and Sublime
data.body:
Some of the basic functions of the missing.
For example:
Block edit, mouse drag and drop selection
Temporary storage is not lost, notepad++ temporary open tab, if you do not save close notepad++, tab content will not be emptied
Multiple line to line pattern
These basic features, atom have to rely on the installation of third party plug-ins.

data.title: Moving tabs between docks does not update dock tab width
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

### Description

Moving tabs to a dock and then moving it back does not update the tab width in the dock until you hover over it.

![docks-no-resize](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/24884688/9ad55a48-1e18-11e7-99e7-a39ff8620421.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a dock and a tab open, and have the dock populated (eg with the Tree View)
2. Move the tab into the dock
3. Move the tab out of the dock

**Expected behavior:** The item in the dock's tab to automatically resize back to full width

**Actual behavior:** Tab does not resize until you drag it or hover over it for a while

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.17.0-dev-4b77f9050
Electron: 1.6.5
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

Issue can be reproduced in safe mode.
(Also note the strange dock resizing after I start hovering over it - not sure if that's related)

data.title: Add `atom.whenShellEnvironmentLoaded()`
data.body:
This provides a way to be notified when the shell environment has loadedâ€”even if it's already happened. (This implements the proposal from #14155.)

cc @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Proposal for Atom project file changed event API
data.body:
## Rationale
The [language-client support](/atom/atom-languageclient) requires that we send messages when files change - even outside of the editor - so we need a file watch api.

Currently we have pathwatcher in text-buffer and some other combinations in different packages. 

What I propose is a central file-watching api for projects baked into Atom that Atom itself and package authors can hook into if they want to monitor for file changes. This will simplify packages, provide a central place for improvements and reduce the resource overhead of multiple watchers.

## Proposed API

As we only want to watch the files that relate to the project and not provide a broad watch-anywhere API I propose a simple event notification from atom.project;

`atom.project.onDidChangeFiles`

The event object is described as:

```typescript
ChangedFilesEvent = {
  changes: Array<ChangedFileEvent>
}
```

And the changes with in;

```typescript
ChangedFileEvent = {
  oldPath: String,
  newPath: String
  type: Added | Changed | Deleted | Renamed
}
```

Each of the types would effectively look like this;

```typescript
addedFile = { oldPath: '~/added.txt', type: 'Added' }
deletedFile = { oldPath: '~/deleted.txt', type: 'Deleted' }
renamedFile = { oldPath: '~/old.txt', newPath: '~/new.txt', type: 'Rename' }
changedFile = { oldPath: '~/file.txt', newPath: '~/file.txt', type: 'Changed' }
```

## Throttling

We should throttle events as to not overwhelm consumers. The api provides an array so they can be batched. 

## Considerations

1. The standard Node api supports recursive watching on Windows (since 5.0) and MacOS however does not provide such a facility for Linux. It also does not support throttling or rename detection.
2. Is Chokidar the right client?  It adds rename/native Mac support/recursive Windows workarounds. This is because it aims to be compatible with much older Node clients. Does it get in the way of more recent ones.
3. Renames may appear as add/delete because of the way other tools handle this (e.g. git). We can either try and resolve that or consider having add/delete instead of rename entirely (simplifies event)
4. The event api supplies an array of batched changes however it will not normalize them so it could easily consist of a file change event immediately followed by a delete event.
5. A folder deletion could cause a massive amount of file changed events. Not much we can do about this I think.
6. File changes will not be recognized on network shares due to limitations of the network file change protocols. Polling is an option but can be resource intensive.

data.title: Fix a regression in hovered dock tracking
data.body:
This fixes a regression introduced in #14143 and backfills some tests for the dock toggle buttons.

This also fixes a minor bug where, after clicking the dock toggle button to hide the dock, the button would remain visible until the next mouse movement.

/cc @nathansobo @matthewwithanm

data.title: Propsal: `atom.whenShellEnvironmentLoaded()`
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Currently, there's no way for a package to know if the shell environment has been loaded other than delaying its activation. You can use `atom.packages.onDidTriggerActivationHook()` to listen for `"'core:loaded-shell-environment"`, but it may have already been triggered. In Nuclide, we currently have [a package][1] whose entire point is to resolve a promise when it's activated by the hook ðŸ˜

The proposal is to add a new AtomEnvironment method that allows you to register a callback to be invoked immediately if the shell environment is already loaded or, otherwise, once it loads:

`atom.whenShellEnvironmentLoaded(cb: () => void): Disposable`

### Alternate Designs

There are currently three precedents for this kind of event handling in Atom:

1. `onDidBlah()` functions which only invoke their callbacks on events subsequent to registration (of which there are implied to be multiple)
2. `observeBlah()` functions which provide the semantics we're after but (currently, at least) imply multiple events
3. `getBlahPromise()` provides similar semantics. (This isn't a strong precedent thoughâ€”the only example I'm aware of is `atom.views.getNextUpdatePromise()`). Looking ahead, though, if more promise-returning methods are added, we'll almost certainly require cancelability at some point. That would probably mean adding cancelation tokens which would fragment the APIs between cancelation tokens and disposables.

The proposed version fits with the established API patterns (callback-accepting, disposable-returning functions) but establishes a new prefix ("when") that has the same semantics as `observeBlah()` functions but is used when the callback will only be called once.

cc @maxbrunsfeld @nathansobo 

[1]: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/tree/v0.216.0/pkg/nuclide-loaded-shell-hook

    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

1. [First Step]
2. [Second Step]
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

data.title: Cannot launch portable atom on WIN10 x 64
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I tried to follow the step to [launch a portable atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/getting-started/sections/installing-atom/#portable-mode), but a got a crash report.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download and extract zip file to `D:\Program Files\Atom\app-1.15.0-x64`.
2. Create `D:\Program Files\Atom\.atom\`
3. Create `D:\Program Files\Atom\.atom\electronUserData\`
4. Startup `atom.exe`

**Expected behavior:** Startup a portable version.

**Actual behavior:** Crashed.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information
```
D:\Program Files\Atom\app-1.15.0-x64>echo %ATOM_HOME%
%ATOM_HOME%

D:\Program Files\Atom\app-1.15.0-x64>la ../

-rwxr-xrwa  1 root                  83 Apr  7 21:24 atom.bat
drwxr-xrwx  1 root                   0 Jan  6 20:30 bin
drwxr-xrwx  1 root                   0 Apr  7 21:29 packages
-rw-r--rwa  1 root                4429 Dec 19 10:15 SquirrelSetup.log
-rwxr-xrwa  1 root             1523752 Jul 29  2016 Update.exe

D:\Program Files\Atom\app-1.15.0-x64>atom.exe

D:\Program Files\Atom\app-1.15.0-x64>

    at start (D:\Program Files\Atom\app-1.15.0-x64\resources\app.asar\src\main-process\start.js:27:13)
    at Object.<anonymous> (D:\Program Files\Atom\app-1.15.0-x64\resources\app.asar\src\main-process\main.js:36:1)
```
